Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Contributions of microorganisms to greenhouse gas emissions from volcanic soils prevalent in the Pacific Rim Region
Award.AbstractNarration:
Soils derived from materials of volcanic origin (e.g. Andisols) play an especially important role in Japan, the United States and other countries around the Pacific Rim with volcanic activity. In Japan, Andisols comprise a large fraction of the agricultural soil resource. Andisols have a large influence on human activities on the Pacific Rim. They are often located in regions with high population density, and have high agricultural productivity. Andisols have unique physical and chemical properties not found in other soil types. This research will examine how the chemical and physical properties of cropped and noncropped Andisols influence the nitrogen (N) cycle and greenhouse gas emissions. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Yuichi Suwa at Chuo University. Dr. Suwa's laboratory has more than 20 years of experience examining nitrogen cycling, and has the resources necessary to conduct this research.

Nitrification is an important part of the global nitrogen cycle in which ammonium (NH4+) is oxidized to nitrate (NO3-). The oxidation of NH4+ is the rate-controlling step of nitrification and is carried out by ammonia-oxidizing bacteria (AOB) and archaea (AOA). Nitrification may promote N loss from terrestrial environments that otherwise would be available to plants. The process of nitrification can lead to loss of N as nitrous oxide (N2O) which is a potent greenhouse gas with 350 times the warming potential of carbon dioxide (CO2), and its concentration is increasing. The process of nitrification is especially important in soils that are heavily impacted by human activities. This study will examine how the nitrification activity and N2O emissions from AOA and AOB in allophanic and nonallophanic Andisols respond to changes in conditions of NH3 availability, O2 tension, and water content. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Soils derived from volcanic material, also known as Andisols, are important for agricultural production. In Japan for example, Andisols comprise 18% of the soil resource, and cover an area of 1.35 million hectares totaling 27% of all agricultural soils. While the percentage of Andisols is lower than most other soil orders worldwide, they have a disproportionate influence on human activities. These soils are often located in regions with high population density, and often have high agricultural productivity. In any agricultural system, nitrogen (N) is critical. Nitrification is the microbe-mediated transformation of ammonium (NH4+) to nitrate (NO3-). During the oxidation of NH4+, the greenhouse gas nitrous oxide (N2O) can be produced, which has a warming potential 300 times greater than carbon dioxide (CO2). A better understanding of the factors that control N2O production from nitrification could allow for improved fertilizer management techniques, which would reduce N loss, and the associated costs. As well as potential reduce greenhouse gas inputs into the atmosphere. This project examined the impacts of N-fertilization of the production of N2O from soil-borne microorganisms responsible for the process of nitrification in volcanic soils planted with corn, in Ninjita Prefecture. This project developed a method for examining the contributions of different soil organisms, using laboratory scale whole soil incubations. Using this method, data was collected that suggests that N2O is produced in measureable quantities from nitrification, and that there different groups of soil microorganism may have different contributions to N2O production. In addition to the scientific benefits of this project, this project also facilitated a collaborative research effort between research groups at Oregon State University, and Chuo University in Tokyo, Japan. This collaboration has enabled sharing of ideas, equipment and facilities, to continue research into this subject.  In addition, this collaboration has opened up further research opportunities.
